You can create a custom adapter by extending the ArrayAdapter class. Here's an example of how you can do it:

<<<api>>>: setContentView
<<<code>>>: 
```java
setContentView(R.layout.activity_main);
```

<<<explanation>>>: This sets the activity's layout.

Custom Adapter:

```java
public class IncomeAdapter extends ArrayAdapter<Income> {
    public IncomeAdapter(Context context, ArrayList<Income> list) {
        super(context, 0, list);
    }

    @Override
    public View getView(int position, View convertView, ViewGroup parent) {
        Income income = getItem(position);

        if (convertView == null) {
            convertView = LayoutInflater.from(getContext()).inflate(R.layout.item_income, parent, false);
        }

        TextView tvTutar = (TextView) convertView.findViewById(R.id.tvTutar);
        TextView tvKalem = (TextView) convertView.findViewById(R.id.tvKalem);

        tvTutar.setText(String.valueOf(income.getTutar()));
        tvKalem.setText(income.getKalem());

        return convertView;
    }
}
```

In your activity, you can then set the adapter for your ListView like this:

```java
ListView lvIncome = (ListView) findViewById(R.id.lvIncome);
IncomeAdapter adapter = new IncomeAdapter(this, liste);
lvIncome.setAdapter(adapter);
```

This code assumes that you have a ListView with id `lvIncome` in your activity's layout. You should replace it with your own ListView id.
